title: ISic000308. Letter of Iulius Paternus to the Emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus
body:
1[Antonino et Vero Aug(ustis) Arme]ṇiacis · suis · Iulius · Paternus · sa[lutem]
2[---]es · pertulissem ut se haberet opus por[tus?. c. 3.]
3[---].m propitii velitis admittere ita me cụ[riae?. c. 2.]
4[---]o vestro in eadem cura remanere debereṃ, qu[a re]
5[---]reficiendam curavi. Cum deinde Catinenses ṃ[unus?]
6[---]quam · pecuniam · dari iuberetis · rescripsi. Set Seị[us?]
7[---]nummos subministraturum · id q(ue) ipsuṃ etiaṃ
8[---]ṃ dari ipsis · iussisset, ut ordine suo scribṭura fieret(vac.1)
9[---]ram transiret · II · viri consensu paucorum de[c]urionum(vac.2)
10[---]cipium. Cum erga procuratorem vestrum iṇreverens v[. c. 1.]-
11[---]ṭe curia ageretur · ingressus petii ut quatẹnus neque(vac.3)
12[---]ṭratibus neq(ue) ṃạgistratus vellent in[termitte]re, ordo[. c. 3.]

1[.......................].IACISSUISIULIUSPATERNUSSA[.....]
2[---]ESPERTULISSEMUTSEHABERETOPUSPOR[...···]
3[---]·MPROPITIIVELITISADMITTEREITAMEC.[....··]
4[---]OVESTROINEADEMCURAREMANEREDEBERE.QU[...]
5[---]REFICIENDAMCURAVICUMDEINDECATINENSES.[....]
6[---]QUAMPECUNIAMDARIIUBERETISRESCRIPSISETSE.[..]
7[---]NUMMOSSUBMINISTRATURUMIDQIPSU.ETIA.
8[---].DARIIPSISIUSSISSETUTORDINESUOSCRIB.URAFIERET  
9[---]RAMTRANSIRETIIVIRICONSENSUPAUCORUMDE[.]URIONUM    
10[---]CIPIUMCUMERGAPROCURATOREMVESTRUMI.REVERENSV[·]
11[---].ECURIAAGERETURINGRESSUSPETIIUTQUAT.NUSNEQUE      
12[---].RATIBUSNEQ..GISTRATUSVELLENTIN[........]REORDO[···]

Apparatus criticus

  • Text of Prag based upon autopsy

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

Three further fragments of one or more very similar texts (perhaps even part of this text) are also preserved (two were found in the late 18th century, the third was found in via Dusmet in 1958), but the relationship between these remains very uncertain (see ISic000821, ISic001664, ISic003153).

Iulius Paternus was appointed by the Emperors as a curator operis (overseer of public works) for Catania. This letter reports his efforts to complete the works and to resolve a crisis over the funding. The works may have been connected with the harbour (portus, line 2, or porticus? one of the similar fragments describes harbour works). The Catania senators refused to pay their part and the work was completed by Paternus with imperial funds. The imperial procurator (called Seius? the financial officer for the island) subsequently tried to put arrangements in place to ensure the city repaid Paternus for the work. This proposal was resisted by the city duumvirs and a small group of senators (acting ‘irreverently’ towards the procurator). Paternus intervened further to resolve the dispute. The letter’s publication – probably attached to the building works - will have confirmed that resolution and publicised Paternus’s actions.
